xxl.cursors
Class Mapper

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--xxl.cursors.Mapper
Direct Known Subclasses:
KPEKPEzCodeMapper, KPERectangleNormalizer, PointEpsilonRectangleMapper, RectangleKPEMapper
public class Mapper
extends Object
implements Cursor

The Mapper maps an input-Iterator-array to a Cursor by invoking a given Function.
This Function is applied to n input-Iterators, that means a n-dimensional function is called and its paramters are one element of each iterator. The result is an element of the output-Cursor.
Also a partial input is allowed with the intention to apply the Function on less than n parameters.

IMPORTANT: The function of the Mapper is called with an Object-array.

Note: Input-Iterators or -PeekIterators are wrapped to Cursors.

Example usage (1): 

 	Mapper mapper = new Mapper (
 		new Enumerator(21),
 		new Function () {
 			public Object invoke (Object[] arguments) {
 				return new Integer(((Integer)arguments[0]).intValue() * 2);
 			}
 		}
 	);
 	while(mapper.hasNext())
 		System.out.print(mapper.next() +"; ");
 	System.out.flush(); System.out.println();
 	mapper.close();
This Mapper maps the given numbers of the Enumerator with range 0,...,20 concerning the above defined function, i.e. x --> 2*x.
The function is applied on each element of the given Enumerator, therefore the following output is printed to the output stream: 
 	0; 2; 4; 6; 8; 10; ... ; 36; 38; 40;
But pay attention the function invoke gets an object-array as parameter!

Example usage (2): 

 	HashGrouper hashGrouper = new HashGrouper(
 		new Enumerator(21),
 		new Function () {
 			public Object invoke (Object next) {
 				return new Integer(((Integer)next).intValue() % 5);
 			}
 		}
 	);
 	Cursor[] cursors = new Cursor[5];
 	for(int i=0; hashGrouper.hasNext(); i++)
 		cursors[i] = (Cursor)hashGrouper.next();
 	mapper = new Mapper( cursors,
 		new Function () {
 			public Object invoke (Object[] arguments) {
 				return Cursors.minima(new ArrayCursor(arguments)).getFirst();
 			}
 		}
 	);
 	while(mapper.hasNext())
 		System.out.print(mapper.next() +"; ");
 	System.out.flush();
 	mapper.close();
This example uses the class HashGrouper to paration the delivered numbers of the Enumerator. For further information see HashGrouper. The buckets of the HashMap used by the HashGrouper are stored in the Cursor-array cursors.
Then a new Mapper is created that maps this Cursor-array to the first element of its contained minima. Therefore the static method minima is used returning a LinkedList, where the method getFirst() is applied.
For the first call to next the Cursor-array contains the Integer-objects with value 0,...,4, namely the first element of each bucket. The returned minimum is 0. The next call to this method returns the minimum of 5,...,10, namely the second element in each bucket.
So the output of this use case is: 
 	0; 5; 10; 15;

See Also:
Cursor, PeekIterator, Function, Iterator

public Mapper(Iterator[] iterators,
              Function function,
              boolean allowPartialInput)
Creates a new Mapper using an input-Iterator array and a user-defined function to map the elements. The flag allowPartialInput defines if the Function can be used with a lower dimension than iterators.length.
Parameters:
iterators - the input-Iterators.
function - the Function used to map elements.
allowPartialInput - true if the Function can be applied to less than one element of each Cursor.

Method Detail

close

public void close()
Closes the Mapper. Signals the Mapper to cleanup resources, close files, etc.
Each input-Cursor is closed.
After a call to close calls to methods like next or peek are not guarantied to yield proper results.
Multiple calls to close() do not have any effect, i.e. if close() was called the Merger remains in the state "closed".
Specified by:
close in interface Cursor

hasNext

public boolean hasNext()
Returns true if the iteration has more elements.
That means if the function can be applied to elements of the input-Iterator-array again. If a partial input is allowed, the function can be applied on only a part of the elements of the input-iterator-array.
Specified by:
hasNext in interface Cursor
Returns:
true if the input-Cursors have further elements.

next

public Object next()
            throws NoSuchElementException
Returns the next element in the iteration.
This element is created by applying the Function to its given arguments, that means the next element of each input-Cursor.
If a partial input has been allowed some arguments may miss, therefore arguments.length can be lower than cursors.length.
The arguments of the Function, namely the elements of each input-Cursor, will be removed from the underlying collections concerning their containing Cursor, when the next method is called.
Specified by:
next in interface Cursor
Returns:
the next element in the iteration.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - iteration has no more elements.

peek

public Object peek()
            throws NoSuchElementException,
                   UnsupportedOperationException
Shows the next element in the iteration without removing the arguments of the Function from the input-Cursors. (optional operation)
If the peek method is called the Function is applied to its given arguments, which are one element of each input-Cursor.
If a partial input has been allowed some arguments may miss, therefore arguments.length can be lower than cursors.length.
The peek method is only supported by a Mapper if every input-Cursor supports the method.
Specified by:
peek in interface Cursor
Returns:
the next element in the iteration.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - iteration has no more elements.
UnsupportedOperationException - if the peek operation is not supported by this Mapper.

remove

public void remove()
            throws IllegalStateException,
                   UnsupportedOperationException
Removes from the underlying collection, the input-Cursor-array, the last element returned by the Mapper. (optional operation)
If the remove method is called, every element, which was used by the Function, when the next or peek method was called, will be removed in the input-Cursor it is included.
This method can be called only once per call to next or peek. The behavior of a Mapper is unspecified if the underlying collection is modified while the iteration is in progress in any way other than by calling this method.
Specified by:
remove in interface Cursor
Throws:
UnsupportedOperationException - if the remove operation is not supported by this Mapper.
IllegalStateException - if the next or peek method has not yet been called, or the remove method has already been called after the last call to the next or peek method.

reset

public void reset()
           throws UnsupportedOperationException
Resets the input-Cursors to their initial states. (optional operation)
That means the caller is able to traverse the underlying collections again.
The modifications, removes and updates concerning the underlying collections, are still persistent.
Specified by:
reset in interface Cursor
Throws:
UnsupportedOperationException - if the reset method is not supported by this Mapper.

supportsPeek

public boolean supportsPeek()
Returns true if the peek-operation is supported by this Mapper. Else returns false.
The peek-functionality is only supported by the Mapper, if every input-Cursor supports the peek method.
Specified by:
supportsPeek in interface Cursor
Returns:
true if the peek operation is supported by the Mapper.

update

public void update(Object object)
            throws UnsupportedOperationException
This method is not supported by Mappers. If this method is called an UnsupportedOperationException is thrown.
Specified by:
update in interface Cursor
Parameters:
object - the object that replaces the object returned by the last call to next or peek.
Throws:
UnsupportedOperationException - if the update operation is not supported by this Mapper.

main

public static void main(String[] args)
The main method contains some examples to demonstrate the usage and the functionality of this class.
Parameters:
args - array of String arguments. It can be used to submit parameters when the main method is called.
